Apple___Apple_scab: Remove and destroy infected leaves and fruit to reduce spore spread; prune trees for better air circulation.
Apply fungicides like captan or sulfur during the growing season, following label instructions for timing.
Choose resistant apple varieties such as Liberty or Enterprise for future plantings to prevent recurrence.
Apple___Black_rot: Prune and remove all infected branches and mummified fruit to eliminate sources of infection.
Apply copper-based fungicides in early spring before bud break to protect new growth.
Improve tree vigor with balanced fertilization and ensure proper spacing to enhance airflow.
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust: Remove nearby cedar or juniper hosts within a 500-foot radius to break the disease cycle.
Apply fungicides such as myclobutanil starting at the pink bud stage and repeat every 7-10 days.
Plant rust-resistant apple varieties like Liberty or GoldRush to minimize future outbreaks.
Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew: Prune trees to improve air circulation and sunlight penetration, removing any infected shoots.
Apply sulfur-based fungicides or potassium bicarbonate early in the season before symptoms appear.
Avoid overhead watering to keep foliage dry and reduce humidity around the tree.
Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray: Rotate crops with non-host plants like soybeans for at least two years to break the disease cycle.
Apply foliar fungicides containing azoxystrobin when symptoms first appear, especially in humid conditions.
Plant resistant corn hybrids and ensure adequate nitrogen fertilization to promote healthy growth.
Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_: Destroy crop residues after harvest to reduce overwintering spores; rotate with non-grass crops.
Use resistant corn varieties and apply fungicides like triazoles if rust is detected early in the season.
Monitor fields closely during warm, moist weather and avoid dense planting to improve airflow.
Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight: Plant resistant hybrids and rotate crops every 2-3 years with non-corn plants to limit pathogen buildup.
Apply fungicide sprays containing propiconazole when lesions are first observed, up to twice per season.
Remove and plow under infected residue to reduce inoculum for the next growing season.
Grape___Black_rot: Prune vines annually to open the canopy for better air flow and spray coverage.
Apply protective fungicides like mancozeb starting at bud break and continue through fruit set.
Remove mummified berries and infected leaves from the vineyard to eliminate overwintering sources.
Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles): Delay pruning until late winter and use clean tools sterilized between cuts to prevent spread.
Remove severely infected vines and apply wound protectants like latex paint on fresh cuts.
Maintain vine vigor with balanced nutrition and avoid water stress to reduce symptom expression.
Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo: Apply copper fungicides in spring before symptoms develop, especially after rain events.
Prune to improve canopy airflow and remove infected debris from the vineyard floor.
Use resistant grape varieties and monitor for early signs during wet, warm periods.
Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening): Remove and destroy infected trees promptly to prevent spread by the Asian citrus psyllid vector.
Control psyllid populations with insecticides like imidacloprid and use reflective mulches in groves.
Plant disease-free nursery stock and implement quarantine measures for new introductions.
Peach___Bacterial_spot: Apply copper-based bactericides during dormancy and after leaf emergence to suppress bacterial growth.
Prune trees to enhance airflow and avoid overhead irrigation to keep leaves dry.
Use resistant peach varieties and remove infected fruit and leaves to reduce inoculum.
Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot: Use disease-free seeds and transplants; apply copper bactericides at first sign of symptoms.
Practice crop rotation with non-solanaceous plants for 2-3 years to reduce soil bacteria.
Avoid working with wet plants and ensure good spacing for air circulation to minimize spread.
Potato___Early_blight: Apply fungicides like chlorothalonil starting when plants are 6-8 inches tall and repeat every 7-10 days.
Rotate crops with non-solanum plants and remove volunteer potatoes to break the cycle.
Mulch around plants to prevent spore splash from soil and harvest promptly to avoid late infection.
Potato___Late_blight: Monitor weather for cool, moist conditions and apply protective fungicides like mancozeb preemptively.
Destroy cull piles and volunteer plants; use certified disease-free seed tubers.
Hill up soil around plants to bury lower leaves and improve drainage to reduce humidity.
Squash___Powdery_mildew: Apply sulfur or potassium bicarbonate fungicides early in the morning when conditions are dry.
Choose resistant squash varieties and space plants adequately for good air circulation.
Avoid overhead watering and remove infected leaves promptly to limit spore dispersal.
Strawberry___Leaf_scorch: Apply fungicides containing captan during periods of high humidity and leaf wetness.
Renovate beds after harvest by mowing and narrow rows to improve airflow.
Use certified disease-free plants and rotate strawberry beds every 3-4 years.
Tomato___Bacterial_spot: Use copper-based bactericides and fixed copper sprays after rain or overhead irrigation.
Start with disease-free seeds and transplants; avoid working in fields when plants are wet.
Practice 2-3 year crop rotation and remove plant debris after harvest to reduce bacteria.
Tomato___Early_blight: Apply multi-site fungicides like chlorothalonil weekly from early season through harvest.
Mulch soil to prevent spore splash and stake plants to keep foliage off the ground.
Rotate with non-host crops and use resistant tomato varieties like Mountain Magic.
Tomato___Late_blight: Spray with protectant fungicides like mancozeb before rain and monitor for symptoms daily.
Space plants widely and prune lower leaves to promote quick drying after dew or rain.
Destroy infected plants immediately and avoid overhead watering to keep foliage dry.
Tomato___Leaf_Mold: Improve greenhouse ventilation and spacing to reduce humidity around tomato plants.
Apply fungicides such as chlorothalonil or copper compounds when symptoms first appear.
Remove lower leaves and infected debris; use resistant varieties if available.
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot: Apply fungicides like azoxystrobin starting at the first sign of spots, repeating every 7 days.
Mulch heavily to prevent soil splash and stake or cage plants to elevate foliage.
Rotate crops for 2-3 years and clean up all plant residue at season's end.
Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider: Increase humidity with overhead misting and release predatory mites like Phytoseiulus persimilis.
Apply miticides such as abamectin when mites are detected, targeting the undersides of leaves.
Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization, which promotes mite outbreaks, and monitor with a hand lens.
Tomato___Target_Spot: Apply copper fungicides and rotate with non-solanaceous crops to manage soilborne pathogens.
Ensure good drainage and avoid overwatering; space plants to allow quick leaf drying.
Remove and destroy infected lower leaves to reduce spore production and spread.
Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus: Control whitefly vectors with reflective mulches and insecticides like thiamethoxam.
Use virus-resistant tomato varieties such as Tyking or Solar Fire for planting.
Remove and destroy infected plants early to limit virus transmission within the field.
Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus: Use virus-free seeds and transplants; disinfect tools and hands between plants with 10% bleach.
Remove infected plants immediately and rogue them from the field to prevent spread.
Control weeds that can host the virus and avoid smoking near plants due to tobacco mosaic relation.
